title: Shugborough Hall Walks

images.title: Simon Huguet / Mill pond, Shugborough Park Farm
images.caption: Mill pond, Shugborough Park Farm. The model farm in the background is managed by Staffordshire County Council.

images.title: Jeff Buck / The Ruin at Shugborough Hall
images.caption: Photograph of the Ruin in the garden of Shugborough Hall

images.title: Jay Haywood / Pagoda and Bridge, Shugborough
images.caption: Pagoda and Bridge. The Chinese-style pagoda-like building and red bridge.

images.title: Richard Styles, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Shugborough Hall

images.title: Adrian Bailey / Essex Bridge, Shugborough
images.caption: Essex Bridge. When viewed from the river, this bridge looks just like any other old bridge, but it's much more fun than your average old bridge! This is a packhorse bridge, built to link the Shugborough estate to the village of Great Haywood. And if you search on the Web for information and photos of it, you'll be in for another surprise: it used to be over twice as long. By the way, it crosses the Trent just below the point where that river meets the River Sow.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / Trent and Mersey Canal at Shugborough, Staffordshire
images.caption: Trent and Mersey Canal at Shugborough. Bridge No 73 carries a footpath between the Shugborough Estate (left, crossing the Essex Bridge) and the village of Great Haywood through a railway arch off camera to the right. Haywood Lock is adjacent to the canal bridge.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / The River Trent at Shugborough, Staffordshire
images.caption: The River Trent. The northern plantations of Cannock Chase cover the hills beyond the grazing lands of the flood plain.

images.title: Gordon Griffiths / The Tower of the Winds View
images.caption: The Tower of the Winds View (geograph 4066451)

description: This circular walk uses public footpaths and the Staffordshire Way to take you around Shugborough Park in Great Haywood. You also have the option of exploring the 900 acre Shugborough Estate with its mansion house and delightful gardens. This does require and entry fee though. The walk starts from the car park at Milford, passing Milford Common and heading to Shugborough Hall. You return with a lovely waterside section along the River Sow. The Trent and Mersey Canal passes along the northern edge of the park so there is scope for continuing your walk through the beautiful Trent Valley along this waterway. You are also right on the edge of the Cannock Chase AONB so you could extend your outing by exploring miles of woodland trails. The Two Saints Way runs right through the area to Lichfield so this is a good way of extending your walk.
